G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This is a Complaint for Modification brought under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, to amend the custody and parenting time provisions of the prior judgment entered by this Court on May 15, 2020.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This is a Complaint for Modification brought under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, to amend the custody and parenting time provisions of the prior judgment entered by this Court on May 15, 2020.

G.L. c. 209B (the Massachusetts Child Cu.raw_text: G.L. c. 209B (the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act)
G.L. c. 209B (the Massachusetts Child Cu.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and G.L. c. 208, § 28, as the parties and the children have been residents of Massachusetts since the original judgment entered, and Massachusetts remains the children's home state within the meaning of G.L. c. 209B (the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act).

*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the Court may modify a custody or parenting order if there has been a material change in circumstances and such modification is in the children’s best interests.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly applies and describes the Massachusetts standard that custody and parenting-time decisions must be based on the child’s best interests, and it contemplates later modification when circumstances change (e.g., possible resumption of visitation and a new removal hearing based on a “contemporaneous record”). While this is a direct appeal rather than a modification case, the court clearly affirms that custody/visitation determinations hinge on best interests and that subsequent changes in circumstances can warrant revisiting prior orders, which is consistent with the stated proposition.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “In Massachusetts the focus in a custody dispute between parents is not on their personal rights but on the welfare of the child… ‘[I]n deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare.’ … Ultimately, the judge must determine that removal is in the best interests of the child… In light of the fact that more than three years have passed since the judgment was entered… we conclude that a further evidentiary hearing is required… to make a decision… on the basis of a contemporaneous record.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The Court must prioritize the "best interests of the child" standard pursuant to *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), while also ensuring that both parents fulfill their shared duties to cooperatively meet the children’s needs.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that, in a joint legal and physical custody removal dispute, the governing standard under G.L. c. 208, § 30 is whether removal is in the “best interests” of the children, taking into account all circumstances. The opinion also emphasizes that joint custody entails mutual responsibility, joint decision-making, and a duty to cooperate and subordinate some personal preferences to make the shared-custody arrangement work. Thus, Mason v. Coleman supports both parts of the proposition: primacy of the best-interests standard and the expectation that both parents cooperatively meet the children’s needs.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
“We conclude that in such a situation ‘cause shown’ pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 30, means a showing that removal is in the ‘best interests’ of the children taking into account all the circumstances…
…‘Joint custody is synonymous with joint decision making and a common desire to promote the children’s best interests.’… Shared physical custody in particular carries with it substantial obligation for cooperation between the parents… it is incumbent on a parent who has been awarded joint physical custody to… make the relationship work.”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: In this case: - Defendant’s new employment schedule creates a substantial interference with his ability to meet his parental responsibilities, as outlined in *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss a defendant’s (or any parent’s) new employment schedule as creating substantial interference with parental responsibilities. Rather, it holds that a working, even ‘hectic,’ schedule of the custodial mother did not justify modifying custody, and that her schedule had improved by trial. The court expressly states that employment outside the home, even with odd hours, does not by itself warrant a custody change, which is contrary to the proposition claimed.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The probate judge found that… ‘[t]he Mother’s work schedule was quite hectic. . . . [Her] schedule is a combination of odd hours and concert schedules. The Father has some flexibility in his work schedule….’ … We note, first, that a parent who works outside the home, even one with a ‘hectic’ schedule, may still be the appropriate primary caretaker and that, standing alone, such employment would not warrant a custody modification.”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: - Frequent delegations of childcare responsibilities to unrelated third parties, such as Defendant’s roommate, conflict with the principles articulated in *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012), which emphasize the importance of a stable and supportive environment for children.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss "frequent delegations of childcare responsibilities to unrelated third parties" as a doctrinal problem or as a primary factor in its custody analysis. Instead, it focuses on best-interests factors such as stability of residence, flexible work schedules, wrongful removal, and parental alienation. While the court does cite a different case (Haas v. Puchalski) as an example where a parent was denied custody because the child would be cared for by multiple providers rather than the parent, that principle comes from Haas, not from Hunter itself. Thus, using Hunter as authority for the specific proposition about delegating childcare to roommates or unrelated third parties mischaracterizes the holding and reasoning of this case.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent. See … Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555, 557 (1980) (denial of custody where home was not ‘settled’ and child would be cared for by multiple providers rather than parent).”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: - The unpredictability of Defendant’s parenting time disrupts the children’s routines, contrary to the guidance provided in *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003), which underscores the importance of stability and continuity.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly emphasizes that in custody matters it is generally in the child’s best interests to preserve existing, stable arrangements and to avoid unnecessary disruption. It criticizes temporary orders that cause a child to be shuttled back and forth and praises stability and continuity with a primary caregiver. While the case does not discuss “unpredictable parenting time” in those words, its core reasoning clearly underscores the importance of stable, continuous, and minimally disrupted routines for children, which is consistent with the cited proposition.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.proposition: Furthermore, Defendant’s inability or failure to exercise parenting time as ordered by the Court constitutes a substantial change in circumstances under *Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Smith v. McDonald concerns relocation and the legal status of an unmarried mother as the sole legal parent prior to adjudication of paternity. It does not address modification of an existing parenting-time order or what constitutes a “substantial change in circumstances,” nor does it discuss a parent’s failure or inability to exercise court-ordered parenting time. Using this case as authority for the proposition that such failure constitutes a substantial change in circumstances misstates the holding and context of Smith v. McDonald.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. … The judge, however, as the court details, failed to follow the statutory scheme.”

*Rubin v. Rubin*, 71 Mass. App. Ct. 48 (.proposition: The Court has consistently recognized that adjustments to parenting plans must reflect the realities of parents’ schedules and capacity to fulfill their obligations (*Rubin v. Rubin*, 71 Mass. App. Ct. 48 (2008); *Ireland v. Smith*, 451 Mass. 546 (2008)).
*Rubin v. Rubin*, 71 Mass. App. Ct. 48 (.support_reasoning: This opinion is an employment discrimination case under G.L. c. 151B concerning alleged disability discrimination and pretext for termination, not parenting plans, custody, or visitation. Nowhere does the court discuss adjustments to parenting plans, parents’ schedules, or their capacity to fulfill parental obligations. Citing this case for that family-law proposition is therefore inaccurate and out of context.

*Ireland v. Smith*, 451 Mass. 546 (2008).proposition: The Court has consistently recognized that adjustments to parenting plans must reflect the realities of parents’ schedules and capacity to fulfill their obligations (*Rubin v. Rubin*, 71 Mass. App. Ct. 48 (2008); *Ireland v. Smith*, 451 Mass. 546 (2008)).
*Ireland v. Smith*, 451 Mass. 546 (2008).case_name: Sweenie v. A.L. Prime Energy Consultants
*Ireland v. Smith*, 451 Mass. 546 (2008).support_reasoning: This opinion is a zoning/standing case about whether abutters presented credible evidence of being “persons aggrieved” under G.L. c. 40A, § 17. It does not concern parenting plans, family law, or adjustments based on parents’ schedules or capacities. Citing Ireland v. Smith, 451 Mass. 546 (2008), for a proposition about parenting plan adjustments is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by this decision.
*Ireland v. Smith*, 451 Mass. 546 (2008).relevant_excerpt: “Under G. L. c. 40A, § 17, only a ‘person aggrieved’ by a decision of a permitting authority has standing to appeal from the decision to the Superior Court… The injury must be more than speculative, and plaintiffs ‘must put forth credible evidence to substantiate claims of injury to their legal rights.’”
